choices: one third the length from the armpit to the crease at the elbow.
two thirds the length from the armpit to the crease at the elbow.
one half the length between the armpit and the crease at the elbow.
the entire upper arm between the armpit and the crease at the elbow.
front.question: A properly sized blood pressure cuff should cover:

cards.back: two thirds the length from the armpit to the crease at the elbow.

front.question: A 29-year-old male with a head injury opens his eyes when you speak to him, is confused as to the time and date, and is able to move all of his extremities on command. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is:
When performing a reassessment of your patient, you should first:
A patient’s short-term memory is MOST likely intact if they correctly answer questions regarding:

choices: look specifically for signs and symptoms of inadequate perfusion.
find and treat injuries or conditions that do not pose a threat to life.
identify less-obvious injuries that require immediate treatment.
determine the need for spinal motion restriction precautions.
front.question: After performing a primary assessment, a rapid exam of the body should be performed to:

cards.back: identify less-obvious injuries that require immediate treatment.

front.question: In the adult, bradycardia is defined as a pulse rate less than _______ beats/min, and tachycardia is defined as a heart rate greater than _______ beats/min.

choices: assess only the parts of the body that are injured.
detect and treat all non–life-threatening injuries.
locate injuries not found in the primary assessment.
definitively rule out significant internal injuries.
front.question: The goal of the systematic head-to-toe exam that is performed during the secondary assessment is to:

cards.back: locate injuries not found in the primary assessment.

front.question: Which of the following findings indicates that your patient has a patent airway?

choices: “Does the pain stay in your chest?”
“Has this ever happened to you before?”
“Are there medications that you cannot take?”
front.question: Which of the following medical history questions would be of LEAST pertinence in an acute situation?

choices: look in the ears for gross bleeding.
assess the rest of the body for bleeding.
front.question: As you assess the head of a patient with a suspected spinal injury, your partner should:
Cyanosis of the skin is caused by:

choices: determine how much carbon dioxide is being exhaled.
assess how much oxygen is reaching the body’s tissues.
trend a patient’s blood pressure and assess for shock.
assess how much oxygen is bound to the hemoglobin.
front.question: Capnography is used to:

cards.back: determine how much carbon dioxide is being exhaled.

front.question: The goal of oxygenation for most patients is an oxygen saturation of:

choices: falsely low systolic but high diastolic reading.
falsely high systolic and diastolic reading.
falsely high systolic but low diastolic reading.
falsely low systolic and diastolic reading.
front.question: A blood pressure cuff that is too small for a patient’s arm will give a:

cards.back: falsely high systolic and diastolic reading.

front.question: Which of the following would the EMT likely NOT perform on a responsive patient with a headache and no apparent life-threatening conditions?
In responsive patients who are older than 1 year of age, you should palpate the pulse at the ________ artery.

choices: all the patients have been triaged.
a physician arrives at the scene.
front.question: Treatment and transport priorities at the scene of a mass-casualty incident should be determined after:

cards.back: all the patients have been triaged.

choices: stable patients who are able to tell you exactly what happened.
all patients with traumatic injuries who will require EMS transport.
patients with a significant MOI and unresponsive medical patients.
responsive medical patients and patients without a significant MOI.
front.question: The systematic head-to-toe assessment should be performed on:

cards.back: patients with a significant MOI and unresponsive medical patients.

front.question: Which of the following is an example of a symptom?
When you use the palpation method to obtain a blood pressure, the measurement you obtain is the:
